facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2457 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Civil Appeal No. 2457 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 29 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 29 of 1959. T. Desai, B. R. L. Iyengar and R. N. Sachthey,

facts.text: Amritlal died on October 18, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. One Amritlal died on October 18, 1944. For the assessment year 1945-46 his estate was assessed to tax on a total income

facts.text: For the assessment year 1945-46, Amritlal's estate was assessed to tax on a total income of Rs. 22,160/- from salary and other sources.

anchor.surface_text: 1944. For the assessment year 1945-46 his estate was assessed to tax on a total income of Rs. 22,160/- from salary and other sources. In January 1946, Anusuya Devi widow of Amritlal encashed high denomination notes

facts.text: In January 1946, Anusuya Devi, widow of Amritlal, encashed high denomination notes of the value of Rs. 5,84,000/-

anchor.surface_text: In January 1946, Anusuya Devi widow of Amritlal encashed high denomination numberes of the value of Rs. 5,84,000/-, and made a declaration as required by the High Denomination Bank Notes  Demonetisation  Ordinance, 1946 that A sum of Rs. 5,84,000/- in numberes were made over

facts.text: Anusuya Devi made a declaration under the High Denomination Bank Notes Demonetisation Ordinance, 1946 that Rs. 5,84,000/- in notes were made over by her deceased husband Amritlal Ojha at Rajkot in April 1944 before his death for her benefit and her 8 minor sons.

anchor.surface_text: and made a declaration as required by the High Denomination Bank Notes  Demonetisation  Ordinance, 1946 that A sum of Rs. 5,84,000/- in numberes were made over and or directed to be made over by the declarants deceased husband Amritlal Ojha at Rajkot in April, 1944, sometime before his death for the benefit of declarant and her 8 minor sons.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disbelieved the explanation and brought Rs. 5,84,000/- to tax as income of Amritlal for 1944-45 from undisclosed source in reassessment for 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: In a proceeding for reassessment of the income of Amritlal for the assessment year 1945-46 the attorney who appeared on behalf of Anusuya Devi stated that Amritlal was from time to time, during the last 30. years of his life, giving gifts to his wife and also setting apart money exclusively for his wife and children and that the fund so accumulated which remained in a cupboard was found after his death. The Income-tax Officer disbelieved the explanation furnished and brought the amount of Rs. 5,84,000/- to tax as income of Amritlal in the year of account 1944-45 from an undisclosed source,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer's decision to tax Rs. 5,84,000/- as undisclosed income.

anchor.surface_text: and with his decision the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed. At the hearing of the appeal before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Anusuya Devi-widow of Amritlal-filed an affidavit in which it was stated, inter alia From time -to, time during our married life,

facts.text: Anusuya Devi filed an affidavit before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal stating that Amritlal made presents of cash from time to time during married life on birthdays and anniversaries, total Rs. 5,84,600/- as stridhan in her possession.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Anusuya Devi-widow of Amritlal-filed an affidavit in which it was stated, inter alia From time -to, time during our married life, late Sri Amritlal Ojha used to make presents of cash moneys to me on occasion of birthday of myself and of my sons and daughter by him and also on the occasion of his own birthday and on the anniversary of our marriage. My husband late Sri Amritlal Ojha used to tell me that these presents of cash money that he made was to make provisions for me and my minor sons and daughter and also to meet the expenses of their education and marriage in the event of his death. The total amount of the money so paid by late Sri Amritlal Ojha was Rs. 5 84,600/-. This amount was my stridhan property and was all along in my possession.

facts.text: Tribunal admitted Anusuya Devi's affidavit but declined to admit affidavit of son Gunvantray as it introduced new facts.

anchor.surface_text: This affidavit was admitted in evidence by the Tribunal, but the Tribunal declined to admit an affidavit of Gunvantray one of the sons of Amritlal, because in their view an attempt was made to bring on record a large number of new facts which were number disclosed before the departmental authorities.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal declined to accept Anusuya Devi's case and upheld taxing Rs. 5,84,000/- as undisclosed income for 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal declined to accept the case set up by Anusuya Devi. Beside pointing out the discrepancies in the statements made from time to time, which rendered her case unreliable, the Tribunal expressed the view that gifts made during a long period of 20 to 30 years companyld number all have been made only in thousand rupee numberes. The Tribunal accordingly upheld that order bringing to tax Rs. 5,84,000/- as income from an undisclosed source in the account year 1944-45.

facts.text: Anusuya Devi applied to Tribunal for stating a case to High Court on eleven questions.

anchor.surface_text: In her application for stating a case to the High Court on eleven questions set out therein Anusuya Devi asserted that in her declaration under s. 6 of the High Denomination Bank Notes  Demonetisation  Ordinance, 1946,

facts.text: In declaration, Anusuya stated Rs.4,94,000/- deposited with Bank of India Ltd. Bombay branch in late Aug-early Sep 1945, transferred to Calcutta branch in account of major son Bhupatray Ojha, who drew self-cheque and received 494 Rs.1000 notes given to her.

anchor.surface_text: in the latter part of August and beginning of September 1945, Rs.4,94,000/was deposited with the Bank of India Ltd. at its Bombay Branch and transferred by T.T. to their Calcutta Branch in the account of the declarants major son Bhupatray Ojha who drew a self cheque for Rs. 4,94,000/- received payment by 494 pieces of 1,0001- numberes  included in the list  and made them over to the declarant.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected the application for reference.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the application. The High Court of Judicature at Calcutta however directed the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal to state a case on the following question

facts.text: Calcutta High Court directed Tribunal to state case on question: Whether Tribunal erred by basing decision on part of evidence ignoring statement re withdrawal of Rs.4,94,000/- by 494 Rs.1000 notes.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Judicature at Calcutta however directed the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal to state a case on the following question Whether the Tribunal erred in law by basing their decision on part of the evidence ignoring the statement made as regards the withdrawal of Rs. 4,94,000/- by 494 pieces of Rs. 1,000/- numberes from the bank?

facts.text: Tribunal stated the case in compliance, noting the statement was materially different and not considered earlier.

anchor.surface_text: In companypliance with the order, the Tribunal observed that the extract from the statement incorporated in the petition under s. 66 1  was materially different from the statement reproduced in the order of the Income-tax Officer and that the Tribunal was number invited to companysider at the hearing of the appeal the truth or otherwise of the alleged companyy of the declaration incorporated in the petition under S. 66 1  and that at the hearing of the appeal the original declaration had number been produced.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered the referred question in the affirmative, holding Tribunal ignored part of declaration and other infirmities.

anchor.surface_text: Bijayesh Mukherji, J., who delivered the principal judgment of the Court observed that the Tribunal had apparently ignored a part of the declaration made by Anusuya Devi that 494 high denomination numberes out of those encashed in January 1946 were received from a Bank in Calcutta in realization of a cheque for Rs. 4,94,000/- drawn in September 1945 by Bhupatray her eldest son that there was reason to doubt that statements referred to in his order by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner were made by Anusuya Devi or her attorney and that in any event opportunity to clear up the discrepancies between the statement made at the time of the disclosure of the high denomination numberes and the statements said to have been made before the Income-tax Officer or before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner ought to have been given to her. Holding that the  1  20 I.T.R 484. order of the Tribunal suffered from those infirmities the learned Judges of the High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the High Court order cannot be sustained as the statement about 494 notes from bank was first made in s.66(1) petition, not before lower authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In our, judgment the order of the High Court cannot be sus- tained. The statement that out of 584 high denomination numberes disclosed by Anusuya Devi 494 numberes were received in realization of a cheque drawn by Bhupatray at Rajkot was made for the first time in a petition under s. 66 1  it did number find place in the statement before the Income-tax Officer, number in the grounds of objection raised before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and. number even in the affidavit filed before the Tribunal.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside. The answer to the question will be in the negative.

facts.text: The entire record of the assessee's case before ITO and AAC was found missing and not traced.

anchor.surface_text: This case discloses a very disturbing state of affairs prevailing in the Income-tax Department. It is a startling revelation that the entire record of an assessees case both before the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was found missing, and has number been traced thereafter. Even if companylusion be ruled out, the persons companycerned in looking after the safety of the important record of proceedings of assessment cannot escape a charge of gross negligence.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal erred in law by basing their decision on part of the evidence ignoring the statement made as regards the withdrawal of Rs. 4,94,000/- by 494 pieces of Rs. 1,000/- notes from the bank?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Judicature at Calcutta however directed the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal to state a case on the following question Whether the Tribunal erred in law by basing their decision on part of the evidence ignoring the statement made as regards the withdrawal of Rs. 4,94,000/- by 494 pieces of Rs. 1,000/- numberes from the bank?

issues.text: Whether the High Court can direct the Tribunal to state a case under s.66(2) on a question of law not invited to be stated under s.66(1)?

anchor.surface_text: When the Tribunal is not invited to state a case on a question of law alleged to arise out of its order, the High Court cannot direct the Tribunal to state it on that question see Commissioner of Income-tax v. Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd.

issues.text: Whether the High Court is bound to answer a question referred pursuant to its direction under s.66(2) even if the question does not arise out of the order of the Tribunal?

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to uphold the view of the Calcutta High Court that if an order is passed by the High Court calling upon the Tribunal to state a, case on a question which does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal, the High Court is bound to advise the Tribunal on that question even if the question does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the High Court may decline to answer a referred question which does not arise out of the Tribunal's order or is academic, irrelevant or unnecessary?

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that the High Court may decline to answer a question of fact or a question of law which is purely academic, or has number bearing on the dispute between the parties or though referred by the Tribunal does number arise out of its order.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Tribunal suffered from violation of natural justice by not giving opportunity to clear discrepancies or ignoring evidence?

anchor.surface_text: That plea was not raised before the Tribunal, and the validity of the conclusion of the Tribunal on appreciation of evidence cannot be assailed before the High Court on the ground that departmental authorities had violated the basic rules of natural justice without raising that question before the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the High Court has power to reframe the referred question to introduce new enquiry on facts?

anchor.surface_text: But power to reframe a question may be exercised to clarify some obscurity in the question referred, or to pinpoint the real issue between the tax- payer and the department or for similar other reasons it cannot be exercised for reopening an enquiry on questions of fact which is closed by the order of the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether a supplementary statement of the case may be ordered to include new material or evidence not on record?

anchor.surface_text: Again, a supplementary statement may be ordered only on the question arising out of the order of the Tribunal, and if the Court is satisfied that the statements are number sufficient to enable the Court to determine the question raised thereby, and when directed may be only on such material and evidence as may already be on the record

arguments.claim: Statement about 494 notes from bank first made in s.66(1) petition, not before lower authorities; Tribunal not apprised.

anchor.surface_text: In our, judgment the order of the High Court cannot be sus- tained. The statement that out of 584 high denomination notes disclosed by Anusuya Devi 494 notes were received in realization of a cheque drawn by Bhupatray at Rajkot was made for the first time in a petition under s. 66 1  it did not find place in the statement before the Income-tax Officer, not in the grounds of objection raised before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and. not even in the affidavit filed before the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: High Court cannot direct Tribunal under s.66(2) to state case on question not raised under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: When the Tribunal is not invited to state a case on a question of law alleged to arise out of its order, the High Court cannot direct the Tribunal to state it on that question see Commissioner of Income-tax v. Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. The reason of the rule is clear the High Court cannot hold that the decision of the Tribunal refusing to state a case on a particular question is incorrect if the Tribunal was not asked to consider whether the question arose out of its order, and whether it was a question of law.

arguments.claim: HC not bound to answer question directed under s.66(2) if it does not arise out of Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to uphold the view of the Calcutta High Court that if an order is passed by the High Court calling upon the Tribunal to state a, case on a question which does not arise out of the order of the Tribunal, the High Court is bound to advise the Tribunal on that question even if the question does not arise out of the order of the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: HC may decline to answer referred question if academic, irrelevant, does not arise out of order, or unnecessary.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that the High Court may decline to answer a question of fact or a question of law which is purely academic, or has no bearing on the dispute between the parties or though referred by the Tribunal does not arise out of its order.

arguments.claim: Plea of natural justice violation by departmental authorities not raised before Tribunal, cannot be raised in HC reference.

anchor.surface_text: That plea was not raised before the Tribunal, and the validity of the conclusion of the Tribunal on appreciation of evidence cannot be assailed before the High Court on the ground that departmental authorities had violated the basic rules of natural justice without raising that question before the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Power to reframe question limited to clarifying obscurity or pinpointing issue, not reopening factual enquiry closed by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: But power to reframe a question may be exercised to clarify some obscurity in the question referred, or to pinpoint the real issue between the tax- payer and the department or for similar other reasons it cannot be exercised for reopening an enquiry on questions of fact which is closed by the order of the Tribunal.

arguments.claim: Request to reframe referred question and order supplementary statement.

holdings.text: the order of the High Court cannot be sustained

anchor.surface_text: In our, judgment the order of the High Court cannot be sus- tained. The statement that out of 584 high denomination numberes disclosed by Anusuya Devi 494 numberes were received in realization of a cheque drawn by Bhupatray at Rajkot was made for the first time in a petition under s. 66 1  it did number find place in the statement before the Income-tax Officer, number in the grounds of objection raised before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and. number even in the affidavit filed before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disputed statement about 494 notes first appeared in s.66(1) petition, absent from proceedings before ITO, AAC, and Tribunal; Tribunal not apprised or given opportunity to consider it.

holdings.text: When the Tribunal is not invited to state a case on a question of law alleged to arise out of its order, the High Court cannot direct the Tribunal to state it on that question

anchor.surface_text: When the Tribunal is not invited to state a case on a question of law alleged to arise out of its order, the High Court cannot direct the Tribunal to state it on that ques- tion see Commissioner of Income-tax v. Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd.  1 . The reason of the rule is clear the High Court cannot hold that the decision of the Tribunal refusing to state a case on a particular question is incorrect if the Tribunal was number asked to companysider whether the question arose out of its order, and whether it was a question of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court lacks basis to find Tribunal's refusal erroneous if question not raised before Tribunal under s.66(1); cites Scindia Steam precedent.

holdings.text: if an order is passed by the High Court calling upon the Tribunal to state a case on a question which does not arise out of the order of the Tribunal, the High Court is bound to advise the Tribunal on that question even if the question does not arise out of the order of the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to uphold the view of the Calcutta High Court that if an order is passed by the High Court calling upon the Tribunal to state a, case on a question which does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal, the High Court is bound to advise the Tribunal on that question even if the question does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court not estopped from examining if question arises out of Tribunal order despite its prior direction under s.66(2).

holdings.text: the High Court may decline to answer a question of fact or a question of law which is purely academic, or has no bearing on the dispute between the parties or though referred by the Tribunal does not arise out of its order

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that the High Court may decline to answer a question of fact or a question of law which is purely academic, or has numberbearing on the dispute between the parties or though referred by the Tribunal does number arise out of its order. The High Court may also decline to answer a question arising out of the order of the Tribunal, if it is unnecessary or irrelevant or is number calculated to dispose of the real issue between the tax-payer and the department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court has discretion to refuse academic, irrelevant, or non-arising questions to focus on real dispute.

holdings.text: the validity of the conclusion of the Tribunal on appreciation of evidence cannot be assailed before the High Court on the ground that departmental authorities had violated the basic rules of natural justice without raising that question before the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: That plea was number raised before the Tribunal, and the validity of the companyclusion of the Tribunal on appreciation of evidence cannot be assailed before the High Court on the ground that departmental authorities had violated the basic rules of natural justice without raising that question before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Natural justice violation plea regarding departmental authorities must be raised before Tribunal; cannot be first raised in High Court reference.

holdings.text: power to reframe a question may be exercised to clarify some obscurity in the question referred, or to pinpoint the real issue between the tax-payer and the department or for similar other reasons it cannot be exercised for reopening an enquiry on questions of fact which is closed by the order of the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: But power to reframe a question may be exercised to clarify some obscurity in the question referred, or to pinpoint the real issue between the tax- payer and the department or for similar other reasons it cannot be exercised for reopening an enquiry on questions of fact which is closed by the order of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reframing limited to clarification, not to reopen closed factual inquiries.

holdings.text: a supplementary statement may be ordered only on the question arising out of the order of the Tribunal, and if the Court is satisfied that the statements are not sufficient to enable the Court to determine the question raised thereby, and when directed may be only on such material and evidence as may already be on the record

anchor.surface_text: Again, a supplementary statement may be ordered only on the question arising out of the order of the Tribunal, and if the Court is satisfied that the statements are number sufficient to enable the Court to determine the question raised thereby, and when directed may be only on such material and evidence as may already be on the record but which has number been included in the statement initially made Keshav Mills Ltd. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North, Ahmedabad 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supplementary statements limited to existing record material for questions arising from Tribunal order; cites Keshav Mills.

holdings.text: The High Court may answer only those questions which are actually referred to it. New questions which have not been referred cannot be raised and answered by the High Court
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court jurisdiction limited to referred questions; no power to introduce new ones; substantive taxability question not referred or directed properly.

holdings.text: The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside. The answer to the question will be in the negative

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside. The answer to the question will be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative procedural errors by High Court warrant reversal; question answered negatively.

holdings.text: This case discloses a very disturbing state of affairs prevailing in the Income-tax Department. It is a startling revelation that the entire record of an assessees case both before the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was found missing, and has not been traced thereafter

anchor.surface_text: This case discloses a very disturbing state of affairs prevailing in the Income-tax Department. It is a startling revelation that the entire record of an assessees case both before the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was found missing, and has number been traced thereafter. Even if companylusion be ruled out, the persons companycerned in looking after the safety of the important record of proceedings of assessment cannot escape a charge of gross negligence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comment on departmental negligence in record-keeping.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the judgment of this Court in Narain Swedeshi Weaving Mills v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax 2  lays down any general proposition that the High Court hearing a reference is entitled to amend or reframe a question and call for a supplementary statement so as to enable a party to lead evidence which has number been led before the Tribunal or the departmental authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In our, judgment the order of the High Court cannot be sus- tained. The statement that out of 584 high denomination numberes disclosed by Anusuya Devi 494 numberes were received in realization of a cheque drawn by Bhupatray at Rajkot was made for the first time in a petition under s. 66 1  it did number find place in the statement before the Income-tax Officer, number in the grounds of objection raised before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, and. number even in the affidavit filed before the Tribunal.
The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

anchor.surface_text: When the Tribunal is not invited to state a case on a question of law alleged to arise out of its order, the High Court cannot direct the Tribunal to state it on that ques- tion see Commissioner of Income-tax v. Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd.  1 . The reason of the rule is clear the High Court cannot hold that the decision of the Tribunal refusing to state a case on a particular question is incorrect if the Tribunal was number asked to companysider whether the question arose out of its order, and whether it was a question of law.
The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

We find it difficult to uphold the view of the Calcutta High Court that if an order is passed by the High Court calling upon the Tribunal to state a, case on a question which does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal, the High Court is bound to advise the Tribunal on that question even if the question does number arise out of the order of the Tribunal.
The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside.

It is well-settled that the High Court may decline to answer a question of fact or a question of law which is purely academic, or has numberbearing on the dispute between the parties or though referred by the Tribunal does number arise out of its order. The High Court may also decline to answer a question arising out of the order of the Tribunal, if it is unnecessary or irrelevant or is number calculated to dispose of the real issue between the tax-payer and the department.
The appeal must therefore be allowed, and the order passed by the High Court set aside.
